description:
Tachysurus fulvidraco, commonly known as the yellow catfish or brown catfish, is a freshwater fish species belonging to the family Bagridae. It is native to East Asia, primarily found in China, Japan, and Korea.

The Tachysurus fulvidraco is a medium-sized catfish, typically reaching a length of around 30 to 40 centimeters. It has a robust, elongated body shape with a broad head and a large, terminal mouth. The fish is characterized by its distinctive coloration, with a yellowish-brown or reddish-brown hue on the upper parts of the body, transitioning to a lighter, creamy-white underside.

This species is an omnivorous fish, feeding on a variety of prey, including small fish, crustaceans, insects, and aquatic plants. It is known to inhabit a range of freshwater habitats, such as lakes, rivers, and reservoirs, preferring areas with moderate to slow-moving water and sandy or muddy substrates.

Tachysurus fulvidraco is of commercial and recreational importance in its native range, as it is commonly targeted by anglers and is also farmed for food and ornamental purposes. The species is known to be adaptable and can tolerate a wide range of environmental conditions, making it a suitable candidate for aquaculture and stock enhancement programs.
